executive_summary: The Candle Manufacturing industry is strongly influenced by consumer spending power. Candles are highly discretionary purchases that compete with other home decor and air-freshening products. Rising consumer spending and new varieties boosted performance. The industry was resilient amid COVID-19 as stay-home orders caused consumers to invest more in household items like candles. However, as restrictions ease and travel resumes, consumers will spend less on household decor, hindering the industry. Revenue is expanding at a 1.7% CAGR over the past 5 years and expected to reach $2.9B in 2023, up 1.1%. Profit will drop amid rising costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Candles are a discretionary home decor product
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Candles have lost value as a light source but resurged as a home decor product, sustaining demand and providing niche markets. As decor, candles are highly discretionary purchases influenced by consumer spending and residential construction.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 restrictions boosted household item purchases
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Amid COVID-19 lockdowns, people spent more on household items like candles. Increased demand and new scented/colored varieties boosted revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile petroleum prices caused revenue volatility
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wax, a major input made from petroleum, has fluctuated in price over the past 5 years, causing volatility in industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Low start-up costs but labor-intensive production
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Candle manufacturing has low start-up costs but is labor-intensive, requiring little capital investment. Low barriers led to exits by firms unable to compete on price against low-cost imports.

Imports, especially from Vietnam and Canada, have risen by offering lower prices from lower wage and regulatory costs in developing countries. This intensifies price competition for domestic manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Steady domestic and international expansion expected
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving trade conditions will drive domestic and international demand growth, benefiting manufacturers. However, challenges like low-price imports and reduced household spending post-COVID remain.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation will increase need for skilled labor
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will modestly expand and consolidate to reduce costs. Larger manufacturers will need to hire more skilled labor as production increases.
Manufacturers focusing on premium niche products like soy or recycled candles will cater to environmentally-conscious consumers and differentiate from low-cost imports.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Effective marketing will be vital for competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition intensifies, effective marketing highlighting unique scents, colors and trends will be crucial for manufacturers to differentiate their discretionary products.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures scented and unscented candles.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - increasing

threats: Price of plastic materials and resin

key_trends: Low-cost imports pose a significant threat. Domestic candle manufacturers are responding to this by focusing on higher quality products.

Candles are highly discretionary and compete with other home décor products. Still, demand increased amid the COVID-19 pandemic as people spent more money on all types of household items, which candles are included in.

Candle manufacturing has low barriers to entry and low start-up costs. Despite this, skilled labor is highly important as the creation of candles remains a craft, to which manual design and production are integral.
Candle manufacturers are under heavy environment and noise regulation
Tariff protection has a significant bearing on a domestic candle manufacturers demand. There is a low level of tariff protection against imports of foreign produced candles.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers are collectively the largest distribution channel for candles. Department stores such as Macy's and Nordstrom's account for a significant share.
Retailers are collectively the largest distribution channel for candles. Home furnishing stores such as Pottery Barn and IKEA account for a significant share.
Retailers are collectively the largest distribution channel for candles. Mass merchandisers such as Walmart and Target account for a share, but no data is provided.
Small specialty retail stores account for 13% of the market segmentation for candles.
Wholesalers purchase products in bulk from manufacturers before distributing them in customized orders and sizes to retailers or other buyers, accounting for 12.1% of the market.
Candle manufacturers sell candles to households and religious organizations through direct channels, including online and through mail-order catalogs, accounting for 11.5% of sales.
Online sales account for 2.6% of the market segmentation for candles.

products_and_services.product_description: Candles that are poured into glass, metal or ceramic containers that hold the wax and are capable of resisting the heat of the burning candle. This is the industry's largest product segment.
Similar to container-filled candles, these candles are poured into jars or containers.
Freestanding candles that typically have a diameter of three inches or more and one or more wicks, coming in various shapes like round, square and hexagonal.
Large candles typically designed to have two wicks and a longer burn time, also known as centerpiece candles. This segment has dwindled in popularity.
Small and cylindrical candles designed to be placed in a votive holder. Traditionally for religious ceremonies but now available in many colors and scents.

tier_2_suppliers: Dye & Pigment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Home Furnishings Stores in the US
Small Specialty Retail Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As with most decorative items, candles are discretionary goods. Disposable income influences the level of demand for them. As disposable incomes increase, consumers have more money to spend on candles. Growth in per capita disposable income represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of Plastic Materials and Resin
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Paraffin wax, which is a form of plastic, is a primary input for most candles. In response to rising plastic costs, manufacturers may keep selling prices constant or raise selling prices. Both scenarios have adverse outcomes; keeping prices constant hurts profit, while raising prices often causes consumers to cut back on purchases as candles are a highly discretionary product.

International trade within candle manufacturing is moderate. As the US dollar appreciates against its major trading partners' currencies, imports become less expensive domestically, posing a competitive threat to US manufacturers. Moreover, an appreciating dollar also makes US exports costlier on the international market, hurting industry performance.

Candles are often used to decorate homes, so a rise in the number of households will result in increased demand for the industry's products. Declines in the number of households pose a potential threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Candle manufacturers endure intense competition from imports, which often compete purely on price.

international_trade_points.trade_title: An Appreciating Dollar Fuels Candle Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the past five years, candles imported from other countries with low production costs have been particularly popular, with industry imports satisfying a significantly higher share of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Have Been Significantly Surpassed by Import Growth
international_trade_points.trade_description: The trajectory of exports is a pain point for candle manufacturers. Exports have declined over the past five years. This is due in part to a rising dollar, which makes domestically produced goods more expensive to foreign countries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Countries With High Income Provide Solid Export Demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: More domestic candle exports are destined for Canada, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and other advanced economies where income and discretionary spending levels are high.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Clean Water Act and Resource Conservation Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Candle manufacturers must follow water/solid waste discharge and airborne pollution emission procedures under these acts.
Establishes limits on air pollutants like carbon monoxide, nitrous oxides, sulfur oxides and particulate matter.
Protects health/environment by reducing toxic air and water releases. Applies to most US manufacturers.
Governs noise emission standards for industrial machinery.
Implemented guidance to discourage public gatherings and unsafe work environments, though easing due to vaccines.

basis_points.basis_description: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers in a relatively low-margin industry.
Candle manufacturers must also be able to deliver a range of high-quality products that have aesthetic appeal.

Imported candles are extremely price competitive as they are manufactured in developing countries with low labor costs. Domestic candle manufacturers respond to this by focusing on higher quality, but this strains profitability.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Candle manufacturing has a low, but rising level of market share concentration.
This rising level reflects a fragmented market that has a mix of a few large companies and many small candle manufacturers specializing in higher value candles and products.
Smaller candle manufacturers have increasingly catered to niche markets, limiting the growth prospects of larger companies.

By catering to niche markets, smaller candle manufacturers tend to produce more value-added candle products, reducing their susceptibility to the increased penetration of competitively priced imports into the domestic market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the single-largest expense category
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include the cost of wax, wicks, fragrances and colorants used in candle production.
Skilled labor is highly important, resulting in high wage costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Companies require skilled workers and designers for many of their products, especially within niche product segments.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Domestic demand is susceptible to import penetration
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since candles are discretionary products, selling prices are the primary demand driver. Rising competition from low-cost imports constrains revenue.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Household income influences niche product sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Candle manufacturers are sensitive to changes in household disposable income and discretionary attitudes toward candle products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Container-filled candles are the largest segment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: This category has grown due to added value for consumers and easier distribution and longer shelf-life benefits.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Votive candles have undergone significant innovations
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Votive candles were traditionally for religious ceremonies but now available in many colors and scents, boosting this segment.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: In response to intense price-based import competition, companies within the industry opt to specialize in the production of premium candles to justify higher selling prices.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Given the presence of competitively priced import substitutes, macroeconomic conditions, such as consumer confidence and disposable income, heavily influence demand for candles.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: The industry's labor costs are significant. To increase margins, candle manufacturers may opt to relocate to areas where they experience lower labor costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Plastic resin, a derivative of crude oil, is a key input in many candle products. Fluctuations in the price of crude oil can have a significant impact on production costs. Other key inputs include wax, wicks, dyes, fragrances, glass containers, fire-safety designs and rules on candle accessories.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: By investing more in capital machinery and equipment, candle manufacturers can minimize labor costs, resulting in increased industry profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Through the increased implementation of capital and equipment, many candle manufacturers can develop technologically advanced products that tend to be more effective and long-lasting than lower cost candles manufactured abroad.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The National Candle Association sets standards for candle manufacturers to improve product quality, enhances safety and facilitates market access and trade.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: The US Department of Commerce imposes a 1.8% tariff on imports of molded or carved articles of wax, although some countries are exempt due to bilateral treaties. Over the past decade, much higher tariffs have been imposed on candles from China.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Given the presence of competitively priced imports in the domestic market, companies face high pressure to lower selling prices. However, companies that specialize in premium products can benefit from favorable demand conditions, boosting both revenue and profitability.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Expenditure on wages in this industry accounts for a much larger portion of revenue than expenditure on capital.

FAQs.question: How specialized is your product selection? What niche markets do you serve that larger competitors do not?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must constantly adapt their candle offerings with new waxes, wicks, fragrances and colorants to meet the dynamic preferences of consumers.

FAQs.question: What economies of scale can you currently leverage? How much would you have to expand to enact meaningful efficiency improvements?
FAQs.answer: Economies of scale enable companies to minimize marginal costs, thereby boosting a company's profitability.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? How have these sold as disposable incomes have risen?
FAQs.answer: Customers will often purchase premium goods in this industry if they are perceived to be quality goods.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuating plastic prices affect your company?
How can you capitalize on the price of plastic decreasing?
FAQs.answer: In response to rising plastic costs, operators may keep selling prices constant or raise selling prices. Both scenarios have adverse outcomes; keeping prices constant hurts profit margins, while raising prices often causes consumers to cut back on purchases, thereby affecting revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: As the value of the dollar grows against its major trading partners' currencies, imports become less expensive domestically, posing a competitive threat to US manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How can you efficiently market your premium products?
FAQs.answer: As disposable incomes increase, consumers have more money to spend on candles.
